name: Garden of the Gods
headline: The Garden of the Gods is public park located in Colorado Springs
facts: The Garden of the Gods' red rock formations were created during a geological upheaval along a natural fault line millions of years ago.
The outstanding geologic features of the park are the ancient sedimentary beds of deep-red, pink & white sandstones, conglomerates & limestone.
The sediments were deposited horizontally, but have now been tilted vertically & faulted into fins by the immense mountain building forces caused by the uplift of the Rocky Mountains.
The main trail in the park, the 1.5-mile Perkins Central Garden Trail, is paved & wheelchair-accessible, running through the heart of the park's largest & most scenic red rocks.
The towering red rock formations come alive when you visit the free Visitor & Nature Center & explore the geology, plants, animals & people of this amazing 1334.64-acre regional park.

name: Rocky Mountain National Park
headline: Rocky Mountain National Park includes some of the highest mountains in the continental United States
facts: The top third of the park encompasses the alpine tundra, a windswept land above the trees.
Landscapes on either side of the Continental Divide feature alpine lakes, forested valleys & a wide range of plants & animals.
With the 1803 Louisiana Purchase, the U.S. government acquired the land now known as Rocky Mountain National Park.
Iconic summer thunderstorms & persistent winter winds are among the forces that continue to shape this majestic landscape.
Rocky Mountain National Park was created on September 4, 1915. Rocky Mountain National Park became a park before the National Park Service was created in 1916.
Trail Ridge Road was built by the Civilian Conservation Corps as part of President Franklin Roosevelt's Green Deal to help Americans recover from the Great Depression.
Cresting just over 12,000 feet, Trail Ridge Road is the highest continuous paved highway in the nation — it is so high that drivers will climb 4,000 feet in a matter of minutes.
The park is home to more than 60 species of mammals, including elk, bighorn sheep & moose.

Besides the charismatic megafauna, the park has more than 280 recorded bird species, six amphibians, one reptile (the harmless garter snake), 11 species of fish & countless insects, including a surprisingly large number of butterflies.

name: Estes Park
headline: A popular summer resort & the location of the headquarters for Rocky Mountain National Park, Estes Park lies along the Big Thompson River
facts: Estes Park, a Colorado town with fewer than 7,000 residents, sits along the Big Thompson River.

As the headquarters for Rocky Mountain National Park, a 265,000-acre area with 359 miles of hiking trails, 150 lakes & nearly 100 tall mountain peaks, Estes Park gets several million visitors each year.
The trendy town is well-known for its abundance of restaurants, spas, hostels, wedding venues, golf courses, shops & entertainment venues.
Home of the historic Stanley Hotel, opened in 1909, which inspried the Overlook Hotel in Stephen King's book, 'The Shining'.
The Estes Park Aerial Tramway dates back to 1955. Robert Herron, a renowned ski lift designer, pursued the tramway project after studying ski lift & tram design in Europe.
The Herron family continues to operate the Estes Park Aerial Tramway, which takes more than 3 million passengers to the top of Prospect Mountain each year.
The name “Estes Park” (or “Este’s Park” as it was first known), was bestowed on the valley by William Byers, founding editor of the Rocky Mountain News.
Estes Park was named in honor of its first permanent Anglo residents, Kentuckian Joel Estes & his wife Patsy.

name: Mesa Verde
headline: Mesa Verde National Park is an American national park & UNESCO World Heritage Site located in Montezuma County
facts: Mesa Verde was established by Congress & President Theodore Roosevelt in 1906.
The park protects some of the best-preserved Ancestral Puebloan archaeological sites in the United States.
The park occupies 52,485 acres (21,240 ha) near the Four Corners region of the American Southwest.
With more than 5,000 sites, including 600 cliff dwellings, it is the largest archaeological preserve in the United States.
Mesa Verde (Spanish for 'green table') is best known for structures such as Cliff Palace, thought to be the largest cliff dwelling in North America.
Starting 7500 BC, Mesa Verde was seasonally inhabited by a group of nomadic Paleo-Indians known as the Foothills Mountain Complex.
The Mesa Verdeans built the mesa's first pueblos sometime after 650, & by the end of the 12th century, they began to construct the massive cliff dwellings for which the park is best known.

name: Royal Arch Trail
headline: Royal Arch Trail is a 3.1 mile trail located in Chautaqua Park to a stunning rock formation located near Boulder
facts: Mesa Verde was established by Congress & President Theodore Roosevelt in 1906.
The park protects some of the best-preserved Ancestral Puebloan archaeological sites in the United States.
The park occupies 52,485 acres (21,240 ha) near the Four Corners region of the American Southwest.
With more than 5,000 sites, including 600 cliff dwellings, it is the largest archaeological preserve in the United States.
Mesa Verde (Spanish for 'green table') is best known for structures such as Cliff Palace, thought to be the largest cliff dwelling in North America.
Starting 7500 BC, Mesa Verde was seasonally inhabited by a group of nomadic Paleo-Indians known as the Foothills Mountain Complex.

name: Dinosaur National Monument
headline: Located in a region of spectacular canyons & mountains, Dinosaur National Monument has produced a large number of complete dinosaur skeletons
facts: Over 1,500 dinosaur bones are still encased in rock in Quarry Exhibit Hall
Originally preserved in 1915 to protect its famous Dinosaur Quarry, the monument was greatly expanded in 1938 to include its wealth of natural history.

Paleontologist Earl Douglass of the Carnegie Museum discovered eight vertebra of an Apatosaurus on August 17, 1909, which became the first dinosaur skeleton discovered & excavated at the new Carnegie Quarry.
The rock layer enclosing the fossils is a sandstone & conglomerate bed of alluvial or river bed origin known as the Morrison Formation from the Jurassic Period some 150 million years old.
The monument boundaries were expanded in 1938 from the original 80 acres surrounding the dinosaur quarry in Utah, to 210,844 acres in Utah & Colorado.
Petroglyphs & pictographs provide evidence that many groups made this arid land their home, including the Fremont Indians & the Ute & Shoshone, who still reside in the area today.
